2.text: Add acid to curdle the dairy.

3.text: Strain the mixture and add salt and other seasonings.

5.text: Bring 1 gallon (3.8 L) of milk to a boil.

6.text: Reduce the heat and add 1⁄2 cup (120 mL) of white vinegar.

7.text: Strain and rinse the mixture, then add 2 tsp (10 g) of salt.

8.text: Remove the excess whey and let the cheese dry for 1-2 hours.

9.text: Chop up your cheese, then store it for up to 7 days.

10.text: Heat 10 quarts (9.5 L) of whole milk to 88 °F (31 °C).

11.text: Add ⅛ tsp (a dash) of mesophilic culture and let the milk ripen for 40 minutes.

12.text: Stir in the annatto, calcium chloride, and liquid rennet.

13.text: Cover the mixture and let it curdle for 40 minutes, then cut the curd.

14.text: Heat the mixture to 102 °F (39 °C) over 45 minutes, stirring continuously.

15.text: Let the curds settle for 40 minutes, then strain the mixture.

16.text: Rest the curds for 45 minutes, flipping them every 10-15 minutes.

17.text: Drain the curd, cut it into 1⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) cubes, then mill the curds.

18.text: Mix in 1½ tbsp (25.5 g) of cheese salt and transfer the curd to a cheese basket.

19.text: Press the cheese at 24 pounds (11 kg) for 1 hour.

20.text: Flip the cheese and press it at 50 pounds (23 kg) for 12 hours.

21.text: Air-dry the cheese for 2-3 days, turning it twice per day.
